commits.message: Log4j Sample; Fix JUnit Version, Test Name

Fix log4j Sample

- Fix spring-web version
Remove rabbitmq-tutorials - now hosted by RabbitMQ

Clean Up POMs - Remove repo.spring.io/repo

That repo is no longer available in artifactory.

Add Publisher Confirms/Returns Sample

* Polishing according PR comments

Fix spring-rabbit-json POM

- Add full Spring repo since we need snapshots
- Add proper version of boot maven plugin

Add @RabbitListener ErrorHandler Sample

Demonstrate how to wire in a global error handler.

spring-rabbit-json DefaultClassMapper to Bean

The mapper should be a `@Bean` so it's properly initialized.

Add spring-rabbit-json Sample

Polishing - Display toString()

Polishing

* Rename `Application.run()` to `Application.runDemo()` do not confuse with the `SpringApplication.run()` and `CommandLineRunner`
* Add the project to the root pom as module

Update to Spring-AMQP 1.3.0.RELEASE

- Also Spring Framework 3.2.8

Add spring-retry to Stocks POM

Also update jackson version.

issue_comments.body:
Thanks for pointing this out - retry is marked `optional` in `spring-rabbit` because we don't want to pull it in if someone's not using retry. However, the stocks sample needs it.

I [added the 1.0.3 version of `spring-retry` to the pom](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-amqp-samples/commit/921bdea938b63d9704a96f4a67b6726b22ab960e) and it works fine for me.

The milestone repo is [declared in top level pom](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-amqp-samples/blob/master/pom.xml#L81) so if you build all the projects, it should work ok (works for me). Can you pull this down and try again?

Many thanks for this but even for a simple change such as this, we need you to "sign" the CLA, as discussed in the contributor's giudelines https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-amqp/wiki before we can look at it.

Thanks!

This is no longer needed; poms are now updated to `1.3.0.RELEASE`.

But, thanks!

poms have been updated to use Spring-AMQP 1.3.0.RELEASE. Please submit another issue if you still see problems.

Thanks

> D:\spring-github>mvn exec:java -Dexec.classpathScope=test -Dexec.mainClass=org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.stocks.Server &

You are running this at the project level.

You need to cd into `stocks` to just run the stocks classes.

I have no idea without seeing the configuration and your class.

> at com.winfan.push.job.handler.Consumer.main(Consumer.java:8)
See here: https://github.com/garyrussell/spring-amqp-samples/commit/c6837f99086f64f24f84db4be90b5e86eaa8e26f

Thanks for pointing this out; you can simply add...

```
server:
  port: 0
```

To `application.yml` to use a random port for each.

We should probably turn off Tomcat altogether though.

I am not familiar with Docker, but this...

>Connection refused: connect

...simply indicates that RabbitMQ is just not running on the server/port you are trying to connect to.
It simply can't be running on the configured address/port.

Yes; we just noticed that repo no longer exists after an artifactory upgrade.

Please use this instead...

```xml
<repositories>
	<repository>
			<snapshots>
				<enabled>true</enabled>
			</snapshots>
			<id>repository.springframework.maven.snapshots</id>
			<name>Spring Framework Repository Including Snapshots</name>
			<url>http://repo.spring.io/libs-snapshot</url>
	</repository>
</repositories>
```
Many thanks @wxlund !!

Please see the [README.md](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-integration-samples#note).

>__NOTE__

>This (master) branch requires Spring Integration 5.0 or above. For samples running against earlier versions of Spring Integration, use the SI4.3.x and other branches.
Sorry - my note is for the Spring Integration Samples (wrong repo; sorry).
I am not familiar with that sample; where are you seeing that error?
Fixed [on master](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-amqp-samples/commit/efc5878b9c7e698c387454add6efa8dace5e52af); thanks.

Just Add a `<PatternLayout/>` element to your config...

	<RabbitMQ name="rabbitmq"
			addresses="localhost:5672"
			host="localhost" port="5672" user="guest" password="guest" virtualHost="/"
			exchange="log4j2Test" exchangeType="fanout" declareExchange="true" durable="true" autoDelete="false"
			applicationId="testAppId" routingKeyPattern="%X{applicationId}.%c.%p"
			contentType="text/plain" contentEncoding="UTF-8" generateId="true" deliveryMode="NON_PERSISTENT"
			charset="UTF-8"
			clientConnectionProperties="foo:bar,baz:qux"
			async="false"
			senderPoolSize="3" maxSenderRetries="5">
		<PatternLayout pattern="%d %5p [%t] %m%n" />
	</RabbitMQ>

Please don't use github issues to ask questions; use Stack Overflow instead [spring-amqp] tag.

Issues are for reporting bugs or asking for new features.
I opened [AMQP-761](https://jira.spring.io/browse/AMQP-761).
`%n` adds the newline; remove it from your pattern.

By the way; capturing the `location` (calling class and line) header is quite expensive; you might want to consider adding `includeLocation="false"` to your `Logger` elements...

	<Logger name="foo" level="info" includeLocation="false">
		<AppenderRef ref="rabbitmq" />
	</Logger>

`Lifecycle`.
Hangover from an earlier example I provided to @wxlund
Generated by start.spring.io (via STS).
`/actuator`

Typo; I meant `/actuator`: http://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/1.3.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT/reference/htmlsingle/#production-ready-endpoints

I would say just remove the `@RestController` unless you object to anything else.

I tried the command line runner, but it runs the `Application` before the context is completely started and blocks the main thread so the messages are emitted before...

    Started Application in 1.224 seconds (JVM running for 1.64)

...which looks weird.

    2017-01-31 15:02:24.059  INFO 90896 --- [yPojoListener-1] o.s.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitAdmin         : Auto-declaring a non-durable, auto-delete, or exclusive Queue (sample.mapped) durable:false, auto-delete:true, exclusive:true. It will be redeclared if the broker stops and is restarted while the connection factory is alive, but all messages will be lost.
    Expected a Bar, got a Bar
    Expected a Foo, got a Foo
    Expected a Foo, got a Foo
    Expected a Bar, got a Bar
    Got a Foo
    Got a Bar
    2017-01-31 15:02:24.173  INFO 90896 --- [           main] o.s.amqp.samples.json.Application        : Started Application in 1.235 seconds (JVM running for 1.641)

This way, we see...

    2017-01-31 15:03:42.740  INFO 90985 --- [           main] o.s.amqp.samples.json.Application        : Started Application in 1.252 seconds (JVM running for 1.758)
    Expected a Foo, got a Foo
    Expected a Bar, got a Bar
    Expected a Foo, got a Foo
    Expected a Bar, got a Bar
    Got a Foo
    Got a Bar

Yes; it's safe, I just don't like the output.

We can change the the method from `run()` to `runDemo()` I suppose.

Hi @winfan !
I see the same 404, but that page says that I should follow with `Contexts known to this server are:`. Hence: http://localhost:8080/spring-rabbit-stocks/

For the `helloworld` you should use the same `mvn exec:java` and use separate consoles for the `Producer` and `Consumer` `main` classes.

@winfan ,

Sorry, but all those your requests sound like "Please, code that for me".

If you don't understand anything, just try to do some PoC and ask us to explain some points, but we aren't intended to do the work for you.

Fortunately RabbitMQ and Spring AMQP are Open Source and there are enough info in the Internet on the matter.

If you still don't know how to go ahead even after reading those docs, maybe this technology isn't for you yet... You just aren't ready to implement something using this AMQP components.

Please, convince me otherwise.

Best regards,
Artem

Hi @jamesWjc !

First of all thank you for attention to this stuff.

From other side it isn't clear what you ask.
Please, rephrase your issue.

And one more point: Spring AMQP doesn't provide any API to get deal with MQTT.
You should refer to the Spring Integration MQTT adapters on the matter: 
http://docs.spring.io/spring-integration/docs/latest-ga/reference/html/mqtt.html

And here is a test-case from RabbitMQ team to test MQTT plugin:
http://hg.rabbitmq.com/rabbitmq-mqtt/file/default/test/src/com/rabbitmq/mqtt/test/MqttTest.java

Cheers,
Artem

Sorry, it is a lack of information anyway...
Please, don't hesitate to express your thoughts. 
Otherwise we aren't able to help you.

Yes, simple `Lifecycle`s aren't started automatically on ctx `refresh()`. Only `SmartLifecycle`s
Closing as non-relevant

Hello, @sdeeg-pivotal !

Thank you very much for your hard work! :smile: 

@garyrussell said me that you are very busy guy, so let me just show you a polishing from my side, but not the whole complex review process on your code.
It is here https://github.com/artembilan/spring-amqp-samples/commit/24f7a561a3c254460fa1874301680b8566d1406d.

The most important thing is `ClientEmulator` instead of your `SpringAwareExecutorWrapper`. Because it doesn't work properly and we end up with:

> Exception in thread "pool-4-thread-1" java.lang.IllegalStateException: The ApplicationContext is closed and the ConnectionFactory can no longer create connections.
>     at org.springframework.util.Assert.state(Assert.java:392)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.CachingConnectionFactory.createConnection(CachingConnectionFactory.java:496)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.ConnectionFactoryUtils$1.createConnection(ConnectionFactoryUtils.java:80)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.ConnectionFactoryUtils.doGetTransactionalResourceHolder(ConnectionFactoryUtils.java:130)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.connection.ConnectionFactoryUtils.getTransactionalResourceHolder(ConnectionFactoryUtils.java:67)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitTemplate.doExecute(RabbitTemplate.java:1278)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitTemplate.execute(RabbitTemplate.java:1271)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitTemplate.send(RabbitTemplate.java:619)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitTemplate.convertAndSend(RabbitTemplate.java:687)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitTemplate.convertAndSend(RabbitTemplate.java:683)
>     at org.springframework.amqp.tutorials.tut4.Tut4Sender.run(Tut4Sender.java:51)

Such a noise is scaring people, who studies the Framework using samples.
Right, I have the same issue there, but the tricky `@EventListener` helps me to overcome it.

Hope I'm not so strict with the code refactoring there, but in most cases it's just an automatic tool from the IDE according to the Spring Framework code style settings.

Looking forward for more contributions!

Hello, @sdeeg-pivotal !

M-m-m. From big height no: you don't need to do anything.
Everything else is just our with @garyrussell routine :smile: .

Your first PR is very cool, strait-forward and even from Gary's perspective that was enough to merge as is.

To make my changes locally (just to play, of course) you should add me to your Git `remotes`. `fetch --all` than `pull artembilan tutorials` to the same your local branch.
We usually share polishing to each other for better review before merging to master.
So, if you'd like you can take a look there and leave your thoughts.

Thank you one more time for the contribution and feel free to come with more!

Will review it over weekend.

Thank you for the contribution one more time!

Would be better in the future to start from the issue if there is some concern. Or even much better from the question on StackOverflow. Otherwise this looks like a spam with appropriate consequences.

commits.message:
Upgrade to spring-boot 1.4.0

Remove redundant dependency and rely on the provided by `spring-boot-starter-amqp`

RabbitMQ Tutorials refactoring

Upgrade to Spring AMQP 1.5.3.B-S to resolve an exception on the `context.close()`

issue_comments.body:
Hi @artembilan - thank you so much for taking the time to review my PR.  This is my first one, and I'm still figuring it out, so please forgive my basic questions, but what are the next steps in the process?

What I think is that I want to grab the code from your fork, review/update/extend, then push to my branch.  When I eventually get my branch clean enough, then you will accept it into the main repo.  Is this basically correct?

What is the best way to get the code from your fork?  Should I reset the upstream on my local copy and pull?  Clone your fork and copy to my branch?

@artembilan I'm interested in understanding your use of the flag to control if the task is run or not.  Is there a possibility that thread scheduler which calls the runTask method would fire after the context is closed and the ContextClosedEvent triggers the contextClosed method?  I would have thought that when the context is closed there would be no more scheduled tasks (and threads running scheduled tasks would be cleaned up).

If this is the case then the ClientEmulator could be eliminated altogether, and the sender objects would add the `@Scheduled` annotation to their method that sends messages.

- Check upper case host name on Windoze
- Fix problem with user admin binary converter in Rabbit 2.1
- Add pauses to prevent RPC errors (timing issue in JInterface?)

issue_comments.body: Added (as one commit). Thanks, this is a nice demo.

I presume all these files can be autogenerated?  So they should be added to .gitignore, not to the repo?  Did you mean to do that and commit them by mistake?  I'd be happy to accept a patch to .gitignore.

commits.message: Fix 'raw type' warnings. No significant API changes.

Suppress serialization warnings

All classes that implement java.io.Serializable are now explicitly
marked with @SuppressWarnings("serial").  This serves as an indication
that none of the classes are suitable for transmission across process
boundaries.  This may be revisited over time and as necessary the
annotation may be removed in favor of a generated serialVersionUID.

Until such time, there Spring AMQP maintains no serialization
compatibility guarantees for any class so annotated.
add snapshot repositories back into parent and sample poms
updated .gitignore, removed unnecessary .gitignores in child directories
reverted version from M1 to BUILD-SNAPSHOT
updated version for stocks sample pom
replaced spring-amqp-core with spring-amqp in samples
AMQP-1 added walk-thru of stock trading sample
renamed RabbitConfiguration to HelloWorldConfiguration in the sync helloworld sample
AMQP-1 added 'async' Hello World walk through
AMQP-20, AMQP-17: upgraded to RabbitMQ 1.8.1 client. Also added a bit to the 'AMQP Abstractions' section of the reference manual
replaced CachingConnectionFactory with SingleConnectionFactory for tests and samples
renamed queue generating method in base config to 'generatedQueue'
adding async example to helloworld sample
AMQP-12 added Exchanges, Queues, and Bindings in a lifecycle callback rather than at configuration time
AMQP-9 removed 'default' from names of template properties
AMQP-3 upgraded to RabbitMQ 1.8.0 Java client
added cglib to dependencies for helloworld demo
updated .classpath files to exclude missing directories and moved helloworld sample's src/test/resources to src/main/resources

add declareQueue to AmqpAdmin interface
additiona docs
XML example to configure AmqpAdmin implementations

Change use of RabbitTemplate to AmqpTemplate.
Javadoc cleanup
AMQP-6 Implement AmqpAdmin interface with RabbitAdmin implementation

issue_comments.body: Yes you are correct.  I meant to add *.ipr and *.iws to .gitignore, but accidentally committed them instead.  I force-updated this branch/pull request with the correct commit.  Let me know if I need to modify this further.

Hello!
  Thank you for your annswer. It builds and compiles only if I'll add this repository in the stocks/pom.xml. Unfortunately, there is one test that is not passed:

Tests in error:
  testContext(org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.stocks.web.ServletConfigurationTests): Error creating bean with name 'marketDataGateway' defined in class path resource [server-messaging.xml]: Cannot resolve reference to bean 'rabbitTemplate' while setting bean property 'rabbitTemplate'; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'rabbitTemplate' defined in class path resource [org/springframework/amqp/rabbit/stocks/config/server/RabbitServerConfiguration.class]: Instantiation of bean failed; nested exception is org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanDefinitionStoreException: Factory method [public org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.core.RabbitTemplate org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.stocks.config.AbstractStockAppRabbitConfiguration.
rabbitTemplate()] threw exception; nested exception is java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/springframework/retry/RetryCallback

This means that there is an indirect dependency on the spring-retry project. Unfortunately trying with both 1.0.3.RELEASE and 1.0.2.RELEASE retry dependency, the test will fail again complaining:

Tests in error:
  testContext(org.springframework.amqp.rabbit.stocks.web.ServletConfigurationTests): Failed to read candidate component class: file [spring-amqp-samples-master\stocks\target\classes\org\springframework\amqp\rabbit\stocks\config\server\RabbitServerConfiguration.class]; nested exception is java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError: class org.springframework.core.type.classreading.ClassMetadataReadingVisitor has interface org.springframework.asm.ClassVisitor as super class

Therefore, can you please tell me what version of spring-retry I need and the maven repository where I can find it? I've tried with 1.0.4.BUILD-SNAPSHOT but I could not find its repository.

I'll look forward for your answers.
Regards,
 Florin

Thank you so much for your patience and such a fast answer! Indeed it works, I just tried and I have log messages including the threadname. Now, a suggestion, that you may or may not consider worth of tracking via an Issue.
By using an AMQP reader program it can be found that a number of different log message fields are mapped to the AMQP message header structure as in this sample: 
```
#contentHeader<basic>(
content-type=text/plain, 
content-encoding=UTF-8, 
headers={
     level=TRACE, 
     location=es.companyname.logging.demo.WriteLogs.main()[23], 
     categoryName=es.tsystems.logging.demo.WriteLogs
}, 
delivery-mode=2, 
priority=0, 
correlation-id=null, 
reply-to=null, 
expiration=null, 
message-id=null, 
timestamp=Thu Aug 10 14:02:03 CEST 2017, 
type=null, 
user-id=null, 
app-id=logging-amqp-log4j, 
cluster-id=null
)
```
When indexing and storing the logs via Logstash and Elasticsearch, for example, there will be always the need of obtaining the threadname, so that each execution path can be isolated for browsing, f.e. with Kibana.

With the patternlayout, now I have log messages as follows:
```
"message":"2017-08-11 17:37:38,104  INFO [pool-1-1] END something to log in one thread\r\n"
```
If I want to obtain the threadname ( 'pool-1-1' in the example), I need to code in logstash a filter to get it out of the message text. Not difficult, but error prone and dependent on message layout. Would it make more sense to have it included in the 'headers' structure, together with 'level', 'location' and 'categoryName'?

The other thing that strikes me is to see that '\r\n' at the end of each text message, I am not including a carriage feed at the end of the log messages, so, why is it there?
Thanks again!
Yes, that was it... Thanks!
